elements.content: By using the methodology of extending the reduced transition-metal-grafted ε-Keggin polyoxoanions with two types of terphenyl-based tricarboxylates of H3L1 (3,5′,3″-position substitution) and H3L2 (4,5′,4″-position substitution), we isolated two polyoxometalate-based metal–organic frameworks, [TBA]9­{[H3PMoV 8­MoVI 4O40]2­[H2PMoV 4­MoVI 8O40]}­[Zn12(L1)4] (1, YZU-103), and [TBA]3­[H4P­MoV 8­MoVI 4O40]­[Zn4­(HL2)2]·0.5H2O (2, YZU-104) (H3L1 = [1,1′;3′,1″-terphenyl]-3,5′,3″-tricarboxylic acid; H3L2 = [1,1′;3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,5′,4″-tricarboxylic acid; TBA = tetrabutylammonium). The combination of tetrahedral inorganic building blocks and rigid triangular organic linkers is expected to produce (3,4)-connected nets. To date, only three types of topologies of ctn, bor, and ofp were identified. Interestingly, in this work, an unprecedented (3,4)-connected (6·84·10)3(62·8)4 topology (labeled as yzu) was identified in compound 1, in which the 4-connected node of {Zn4-ε-Keggin} maintains the tetrahedral extending and the L1 ligand exerts the triangular linking role. However, under the influence of a 4,5′,4″-substitued ligand of H3L2, the 4-connected node of {Zn4-ε-Keggin} exhibits the distorted tetrahedral extending, as a result, a 2D network of 44 topology is formed in compound 2, in which the HL2 ligand acts as an angular linker. Moreover, it is expected that the entrapment of POMs in a 3D configuration could induce huge enhancement of their electrocatalytic activity. Therefore, compounds 1 and 2 were employed as electrocatalysts for the electrocatalytic reduction of bromate.

elements.content: By virtue of a 3,5′,3″-substituted terphenyl-based tricarboxylate H3L1, a polyoxometalate-based metal−organic framework of YZU-103 was constructed, which exhibits an unprecedented (3,4)-connected (6·84·10)3(62·8)4 topology (labeled as yzu) on the basis of tetrahedral {Zn4-ε-Keggin} building block. To date, only three types of topologies of ctn, bor, and ofp were identified for the (3,4)-connected nets.
elements.clean_text: By virtue of a 3,5',3"-substituted terphenyl-based tricarboxylate H3L1, a polyoxometalate-based metal-organic framework of YZU-103 was constructed, which exhibits an unprecedented (3,4)-connected (6⋅84⋅10)3(62⋅8)4 topology (labeled as yzu) on the basis of tetrahedral {Zn4-ε-Keggin} building block. To date, only three types of topologies of ctn, bor, and ofp were identified for the (3,4)-connected nets.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), known as organic–inorganic hybrid solids with infinite, uniform, and porous framework structures, are built from organic linkers and inorganic metal (or metal-containing cluster) nodes. Owing to their permanent porosity, high surface area, large pore volume, and adjustable pore size and shape, MOFs have been extensively investigated in the past decades and have shown promising applications in gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, adsorption of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and drug delivery. However, their potential commercial applications are usually limited by the weak thermal and chemical stabilities, which are the critical properties for commercial sorbents. For instance, most MOFs, in particular, zinc-based MOFs, are moisture-sensitive because the relative weak metal–oxygen coordination allows for attack by water molecules, resulting in the phase transformation and decomposition of the framework. Therefore, it is quite urgent to discover new high-surface-area MOFs that are stable toward diverse environments such as air, water, acidic and basic media, and even extreme temperatures and pressures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), known as organic-inorganic hybrid solids with infinite, uniform, and porous framework structures, are built from organic linkers and inorganic metal (or metal-containing cluster) nodes. Owing to their permanent porosity, high surface area, large pore volume, and adjustable pore size and shape, MOFs have been extensively investigated in the past decades and have shown promising applications in gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, adsorption of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and drug delivery. However, their potential commercial applications are usually limited by the weak thermal and chemical stabilities, which are the critical properties for commercial sorbents. For instance, most MOFs, in particular, zinc-based MOFs, are moisture-sensitive because the relative weak metal-oxygen coordination allows for attack by water molecules, resulting in the phase transformation and decomposition of the framework. Therefore, it is quite urgent to discover new high-surface-area MOFs that are stable toward diverse environments such as air, water, acidic and basic media, and even extreme temperatures and pressures.

elements.content: Polyoxometalate (POM) ions, which represent a well-defined library of inorganic building blocks of nanoscopic scale with oxygen-rich surfaces, are ideal candidates for the design and construction of tailored POM-encapsulating or POM-templated framework materials. Replacing the metal ions (or metal clusters) in the routine MOFs with size-matched polyoxoanions to construct POM-based MOFs materials (POMOFs) combining well-defined and stable crystalline porous structures, high surface areas, and regular and tunable cavities is an important and challenging task for inorganic chemists. Additionally, POM materials are endowed with particular multifunctionality, for example, strong Brønsted acidity, reversible oxidization properties, and high catalytically active site density. Intrigued by their unique characteristics, novel structures on the basis of M-ε-Keggin building block, Ni6(μ3-OH)3-XW9O34, M-[Mo8O26], M-[PMoVI 8­MoV 4­VIV 4O42], and M-[P3Mo6­O29], are continually increasing, which demonstrate great potential for application in fields of catalysis, electrocatalysis, and proton conductivity. Preeminent among these examples is the effort to extend the tetrahedral Zn4-ε-Keggin building block by 2-connected benzenedicarboxylates (such as 1,3- and 1,4-) and 3-connected benzene tricarboxylate (1,3,5-) in Dolbecq’s original work.

Replacing the metal ions (or metal clusters) in the routine MOFs with size-matched polyoxoanions to construct POM-based MOFs materials (POMOFs) combining well-defined and stable crystalline porous structures, high surface areas, and regular and tunable cavities is an important and challenging task for inorganic chemists. Additionally, POM materials are endowed with particular multifunctionality, for example, strong Brønsted acidity, reversible oxidization properties, and high catalytically active site density. Intrigued by their unique characteristics, novel structures on the basis of M-ε-Keggin building block, Ni6(μ3-OH)3-XW9O34, M-[Mo8O26], M-[PMoVI 8MoV 4VIV 4O42], and M-[P3Mo6O29], are continually increasing, which demonstrate great potential for application in fields of catalysis, electrocatalysis, and proton conductivity. Preeminent among these examples is the effort to extend the tetrahedral Zn4-ε-Keggin building block by 2-connected benzenedicarboxylates (such as 1,3- and 1,4-) and 3-connected benzene tricarboxylate (1,3,5-) in Dolbecq's original work.

elements.content: The combination of tetrahedral inorganic building blocks and rigid triangular organic linkers is expected to produce (3,4)-connected nets. As far as we know, only three types of topologies of ctn {(86)3(83)4}, bor {(62·84)3(63)4},and ofp {(64·82)3(63)4} are available to us for the (3,4)-connected nets, and there are only a few examples of them. When the 1,3,5-trimetate (H3BTC) was introduced to the highly reduced Zn4-ε-Keggin system, a porous (3,4)-connected ofp-like POMOFs of ε­(trim)4/3, [TBA]3­[ε-PMoV 8­MoVI 4­O36(OH)4­Zn4]­[BTC]4/3·6H2O, was isolated by Dolbecq et al., which represents the first report of ofp. Further investigation employing the expanded tripodal bridging ligand of H3BTB (1,3,5-tris­(4-carboxyphenyl)-benzene) brings out one twofold interpenetrated 3D framework of [TBA]3­[ε-PMoV 8­MoVI 4O36­(OH)4­Zn4]­(BTB)4/3·xGuest (NENU-500) with ctn topology. It is interesting to note that, though H3BTC and H3BTB are both triangular linkers with symmetrically substituted carboxylate groups, compounds ε­(trim)4/3 and NENU-500, on the basis of tetrahedral Zn4-ε-Keggin node, exhibit two distinct types of topologies. These facts indicate that the elongated linkers will create more structural diversity via the rotation of the aromatic ring.

Further investigation employing the expanded tripodal bridging ligand of H3BTB (1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)-benzene) brings out one twofold interpenetrated 3D framework of [TBA]3[ε-PMoV 8MoVI 4O36(OH)4Zn4](BTB)4/3⋅xGuest (NENU-500) with ctn topology. It is interesting to note that, though H3BTC and H3BTB are both triangular linkers with symmetrically substituted carboxylate groups, compounds ε(trim)4/3 and NENU-500, on the basis of tetrahedral Zn4-ε-Keggin node, exhibit two distinct types of topologies. These facts indicate that the elongated linkers will create more structural diversity via the rotation of the aromatic ring.

elements.content: Recently, we devoted our efforts to isolate the ε-Keggin based POMOFs family using angular or triangular organic carboxylates. A series of 2D or 3D (3,6)-connected frameworks, such as [TBA]3­[H4P­Mo8 V­Mo4 VIO40­Zn4]­[C7H6­(COO)2]2 (labeled as YZU-101) and [TBA]6­[H3P­Mo12O40]2­[Zn8­(BTB)2]·(∼38H2O) (labeled as YZU-100), were isolated in our group. We present herein the combination of two terphenyl-based isosceles triangular linkers () of 3,5′,3″-substituted H3L1 ([1,1′;3′,1″-terphenyl]-3,5′,3″-tricarboxylic acid) and 4,5′,4″-substituted H3L2 ([1,1′;3′,1″-terphenyl]-4,5′,4″-tricarboxylic acid) with the highly reduced Zn4-ε-Keggin building block. We isolated successfully a (3,4)-connected framework of YZU-103, [TBA]9­{[H3P­MoV 8­MoVI 4O40]2­[H2P­MoV 4MoVI 8­O40]}­[Zn12(L1)4] (1), on the basis of tetrahedral node of Zn4-ε-Keggin, which exhibits an unprecedented topology of (6·84·10)3(62·8)4 (labeled as yzu). Moreover, by virtue of 4,5′,4″-substituted H3L2, a 2D (44) network of YZU-104, [TBA]3­[H4P­MoV 8MoVI 4­O40]­[Zn4(HL2)2]·0.5H2O (2), was obtained instead, in which the 4-connected {Zn4-(HL2)2-ε-Keggin} subunit exhibits distorted tetrahedral geometry through the linkage of L2 ligands. The electrocatalytic activities of them toward bromate reduction were examined.

We present herein the combination of two terphenyl-based isosceles triangular linkers () of 3,5',3"-substituted H3L1 ([1,1';3',1"-terphenyl]-3,5',3"-tricarboxylic acid) and 4,5',4"-substituted H3L2 ([1,1';3',1"-terphenyl]-4,5',4"-tricarboxylic acid) with the highly reduced Zn4-ε-Keggin building block. We isolated successfully a (3,4)-connected framework of YZU-103, [TBA]9{[H3PMoV 8MoVI 4O40]2[H2PMoV 4MoVI 8O40]}[Zn12(L1)4] (1), on the basis of tetrahedral node of Zn4-ε-Keggin, which exhibits an unprecedented topology of (6⋅84⋅10)3(62⋅8)4 (labeled as yzu). elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used as received. FTIR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analyses were performed on a TG/DSC Model STA 449 F3 Netzsch instrument at a ramp rate of 5 °C min–1. Powder XRD data were collected with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation on a Bruker-AXS D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer in the angular range 2θ = 5–50° at 298 K. Each pattern is recorded with a 2 s per step scan. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. Elemental analyses for Zn and Mo were performed on an Inductively Coupled Plasma Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES DV7300, PerkinElmer, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used as received. FTIR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analyses were performed on a TG/DSC Model STA 449 F3 Netzsch instrument at a ramp rate of 5 °C min-1. Powder XRD data were collected with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation on a Bruker-AXS D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer in the angular range 2θ = 5-50° at 298 K. Each pattern is recorded with a 2 s per step scan. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. Elemental analyses for Zn and Mo were performed on an Inductively Coupled Plasma Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES DV7300, PerkinElmer, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV).

elements.content: 10.0 mL of distilled water was added to a beaker, which contains Na2MoO4·2H2O (1.26 g, 5.20 mmol), Mo powder (0.10 g, 1.04 mmol), ZnCl2 (0.28 g, 2.00 mmol), H3PO3 (0.05 g, 0.56 mmol), and tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH, 0.25 g, 0.77 mmol) with stirring for 20 min. Next, the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 3.6 with 2 mol/L HCl and then the mixture was stirred for another 30 min followed by the addition of H3L1 (0.11 g, 0.30 mmol). Then the mixture was transferred and sealed in a 23.0 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, and heated at 180 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals 1 were collected and dried in air (yield: ca. 0.70 g). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C76H128N3PMo12O48Zn4: C, 27.67; H, 3.88; N, 1.27; Zn, 7.93; Mo, 34.93%; Found: C, 27.62; H, 3.82; N, 1.21; Zn, 7.85; Mo, 34.88%. Prominent FT-IR peaks for 1 (KBr Pellet, cm–1): 2960(s), 2877(s), 1719­(w), 1568(s), 1465­(m), 1366(s), 1164 (m), 1061 (w), 937(s), 818(s), 782(s), 699(s), 585(s), 549­(m), 491­(m).

Synthesis of [TBA]9{[H3PMo12O40]2[H2PMo12O40]}[Zn12(L1)4] (YZU-103) (1)

10.0 mL of distilled water was added to a beaker, which contains Na2MoO4⋅2H2O (1.26 g, 5.20 mmol), Mo powder (0.10 g, 1.04 mmol), ZnCl2 (0.28 g, 2.00 mmol), H3PO3 (0.05 g, 0.56 mmol), and tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH, 0.25 g, 0.77 mmol) with stirring for 20 min. Next, the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 3.6 with 2 mol/L HCl and then the mixture was stirred for another 30 min followed by the addition of H3L1 (0.11 g, 0.30 mmol). Then the mixture was transferred and sealed in a 23.0 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, and heated at 180 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals 1 were collected and dried in air (yield: ca. 0.70 g). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C76H128N3PMo12O48Zn4: C, 27.67; H, 3.88; N, 1.27; Zn, 7.93; Mo, 34.93%; Found: C, 27.62; H, 3.82; N, 1.21; Zn, 7.85; Mo, 34.88%. Prominent FT-IR peaks for 1 (KBr Pellet, cm-1): 2960(s), 2877(s), 1719(w), 1568(s), 1465(m), 1366(s), 1164 (m), 1061 (w), 937(s), 818(s), 782(s), 699(s), 585(s), 549(m), 491(m).

Synthesis of [TBA]3[H4PMo12O40][Zn4(HL2)2]⋅0.5H2O (YZU-104) (2)

The preparation of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that H3L2 was used instead of H3L1, and the reaction mixture was adjusted to pH 4.0 and then heated at 200 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals 2 were collected and dried in air (yield: ca. 0.76 g). elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 150 K for 1 and room temperature for 2. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL package. The crystal data and structure refinement results of compounds 1–2 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and bond valence calculation results are listed in Table S1. For compound 1, the anionic framework of {[H3PMo12O40]2[H2PMo12O40]­[Zn12(L1)4]}9– was successfully located and refined. However, the TBA+ ions were not found, but included in the molecular formula, due to the weak diffraction and large molecular volume of 67839(8) Å3. Such situation was not improved even by elongating the detector distance or using the Cu Kα monochromated radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at low temperature of 150 K. The existence of TBA+ was confirmed by the characterization of IR spectrum, TG analyses, and elemental analyses. The structure was further treated by the PLATON/SQUEEZE procedure. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all Mo, Zn, P atoms and part of C and O atoms. For compound 2, anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all Mo, Zn, P, O, and C atoms. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon positions were placed in geometrically calculated positions. The hydrogen atoms attached to O1w (in 2) and bridging oxygen atoms were not found but included in the structural formula. Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper has been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC numbers 1549068–1549069 for 1–2.

X-ray Crystallographic Study

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 150 K for 1 and room temperature for 2. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL package. The crystal data and structure refinement results of compounds 1-2 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and bond valence calculation results are listed in Table S1. For compound 1, the anionic framework of {[H3PMo12O40]2[H2PMo12O40][Zn12(L1)4]}9- was successfully located and refined. However, the TBA+ ions were not found, but included in the molecular formula, due to the weak diffraction and large molecular volume of 67839(8) Å3. Such situation was not improved even by elongating the detector distance or using the Cu Kα monochromated radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at low temperature of 150 K. The existence of TBA+ was confirmed by the characterization of IR spectrum, TG analyses, and elemental analyses. The structure was further treated by the PLATON/SQUEEZE procedure. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all Mo, Zn, P atoms and part of C and O atoms. For compound 2, anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all Mo, Zn, P, O, and C atoms. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon positions were placed in geometrically calculated positions. The hydrogen atoms attached to O1w (in 2) and bridging oxygen atoms were not found but included in the structural formula. Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper has been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC numbers 1549068-1549069 for 1-2.

A modified glassy carbon electrode (GCE, d = 3 mm) served as working electrode, Pt gauze as the counter electrode, and a Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) electrode as the reference electrode. All experiments were performed at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Studies

A CHI 660D Electrochemical workstation connected to a computer was used for control of the electrochemical measurements and for data collection. A conventional three-electrode system was used. A modified glassy carbon electrode (GCE, d = 3 mm) served as working electrode, Pt gauze as the counter electrode, and a Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) electrode as the reference electrode. All experiments were performed at room temperature.

elements.content: POMOFs modified GCEs were used to assess the solid-state electrochemical behaviors of the POMOFs. It was prepared as follows: an ink mixture of 15.0 mg carbon black (Vulcan XC-72R) and 8.0 mg as-synthesized POMOFs was ultrasonically dispersed into 1.0 mL of ethanol for 30 min. Prior to modification, the GCE was polished carefully with 0.05 μm alumina powders and then cleaned with ethanol, 0.1 M H2SO4, and deionized water, respectively. A 20 μL suspension was deposited onto the GCE. The assembly was covered with 0.5 wt % Nafion solution (50 μL) and allowed to dry in air at room temperature before electrochemical experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Working Electrodes

POMOFs modified GCEs were used to assess the solid-state electrochemical behaviors of the POMOFs. It was prepared as follows: an ink mixture of 15.0 mg carbon black (Vulcan XC-72R) and 8.0 mg as-synthesized POMOFs was ultrasonically dispersed into 1.0 mL of ethanol for 30 min. Prior to modification, the GCE was polished carefully with 0.05 μm alumina powders and then cleaned with ethanol, 0.1 M H2SO4, and deionized water, respectively. A 20 μL suspension was deposited onto the GCE. The assembly was covered with 0.5 wt % Nafion solution (50 μL) and allowed to dry in air at room temperature before electrochemical experiments.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses demonstrate that the building block is the 4-connected ε-Keggin polyoxoanion in both 1 and 2. The classic eight electron-reduced ε-Keggin core has the general formula of [ε-H x PMoV 8MoVI 4O40] x−11, which is derived formally from the α-Keggin isomer by rotation of all four Mo3O13 group by 60° rotations around the C 3 axis. The 12 Mo atoms lie on the vertices of a truncated tetrahedron (Figure S1). In compound 1, there are two types of electron delocalization styles for the ε-Keggin core, that is, eight electron-reduced {ε-H3PMo12O40}8– (ε-Keggin 1) and four electron-reduced {ε-H2PMo12O40}5– (ε-Keggin 2), as shown in a and b, respectively. The oxidation state of the Mo atoms and the protonated bridging O atoms in each building block are identified by overall charge balance and bond valence calculation, as shown in Table S1. The BVS afford +64.6 and +69.0 for 12 Mo in ε-Keggin 1 and ε-Keggin 2, respectively, in compound 1, which are corresponding to {ε-H3PMoV 8MoVI 4O40}8– and {ε-H2PMoV 4MoVI 8O40}5–, respectively. O14, O29, O45 in ε-Keggin 1, and O53 in ε-Keggin 2 are identified to be the protonated bridging oxygen. For compound 2, the BVS afford +64.9 for 12 Mo, as a result, we deduce that the formula for ε-Keggin in 2 is {ε-H4PMoV 8MoVI 4O40}7– with four protonated bridging O atoms of O22, O23, O24, and O29 (c). The remaining charges are compensated by the counter cations. The oxidation states of Mo for compounds 1 and 2 are supported by XPS measurements, which were performed in the energy zones of Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 (Figure S2). The XPS of both compounds exhibit four overlapped peaks at 231.6, 234.7, 232.7, and 235.6 eV for 1 and 231.4, 234.6, 232.6, and 235.6 eV for 2 in the Mo 3d district, which can be attributed to Mo5+ and Mo6+, respectively. The MoV and MoVI binding energies match well with the literature values. Moreover, the P 2p appears at 132.8 and 133.2 eV, respectively, for 1 and 2, which are characteristic of P5+ in phosphates (Figure S3). The P–O bond distances in the central PO4 tetrahedron lie in the expected range of 1.53(2)–1.64(3) Å for 1, and 1.546(3)–1.553(3) Å for 2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of the Basic Building Block

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses demonstrate that the building block is the 4-connected ε-Keggin polyoxoanion in both 1 and 2. The classic eight electron-reduced ε-Keggin core has the general formula of [ε-H x PMoV 8MoVI 4O40] x-11, which is derived formally from the α-Keggin isomer by rotation of all four Mo3O13 group by 60° rotations around the C 3 axis. The 12 Mo atoms lie on the vertices of a truncated tetrahedron (Figure S1). In compound 1, there are two types of electron delocalization styles for the ε-Keggin core, that is, eight electron-reduced {ε-H3PMo12O40}8- (ε-Keggin 1) and four electron-reduced {ε-H2PMo12O40}5- (ε-Keggin 2), as shown in a and b, respectively. The oxidation state of the Mo atoms and the protonated bridging O atoms in each building block are identified by overall charge balance and bond valence calculation, as shown in Table S1. The BVS afford +64.6 and +69.0 for 12 Mo in ε-Keggin 1 and ε-Keggin 2, respectively, in compound 1, which are corresponding to {ε-H3PMoV 8MoVI 4O40}8- and {ε-H2PMoV 4MoVI 8O40}5-, respectively. O14, O29, O45 in ε-Keggin 1, and O53 in ε-Keggin 2 are identified to be the protonated bridging oxygen. For compound 2, the BVS afford +64.9 for 12 Mo, as a result, we deduce that the formula for ε-Keggin in 2 is {ε-H4PMoV 8MoVI 4O40}7- with four protonated bridging O atoms of O22, O23, O24, and O29 (c). The remaining charges are compensated by the counter cations. The oxidation states of Mo for compounds 1 and 2 are supported by XPS measurements, which were performed in the energy zones of Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 (Figure S2). The XPS of both compounds exhibit four overlapped peaks at 231.6, 234.7, 232.7, and 235.6 eV for 1 and 231.4, 234.6, 232.6, and 235.6 eV for 2 in the Mo 3d district, which can be attributed to Mo5+ and Mo6+, respectively. The MoV and MoVI binding energies match well with the literature values. Moreover, the P 2p appears at 132.8 and 133.2 eV, respectively, for 1 and 2, which are characteristic of P5+ in phosphates (Figure S3). The P-O bond distances in the central PO4 tetrahedron lie in the expected range of 1.53(2)-1.64(3) Å for 1, and 1.546(3)-1.553(3) Å for 2.

elements.content: Representations of the tetrahedral connection mode of {Zn4-L1-ε-Keggin-1} (a) and {Zn4-L1-ε-Keggin-2} (b) in 1; Representations of the distorted tetrahedral connection mode of {Zn4-(HL2)2-ε-Keggin} in 2.
elements.clean_text: 1  Representations of the tetrahedral connection mode of {Zn4-L1-ε-Keggin-1} (a) and {Zn4-L1-ε-Keggin-2} (b) in 1; Representations of the distorted tetrahedral connection mode of {Zn4-(HL2)2-ε-Keggin} in 2.

elements.content: The ε-Keggin cores are further stabilized by four tetrahedral coordinated ZnII ions capping on the four hexangular windows of the POM. The obtained Zn4-ε-Keggin maintains the T d symmetry of the ε-Keggin. Each Zn4-ε-Keggin unit is further linked by L1/L2 ligand using one carboxylate group in it in a monodentate coordination mode. The obtained {Zn4-L1-ε-Keggin-1} and {Zn4-L1-ε-Keggin-2} units in 1 also maintain the tetrahedral geometry with the intersection angles of 109 ± 4° and 109 ± 2°, respectively. However, the {Zn4-(HL2)2-ε-Keggin} in compound 2 exhibits a distorted tetrahedral geometry with the intersection angles ranging from 98.5° to 126.9°.

However, the {Zn4-(HL2)2-ε-Keggin} in compound 2 exhibits a distorted tetrahedral geometry with the intersection angles ranging from 98.5° to 126.9°.

elements.content: The crystalline homogeneity of compounds 1 and 2 has been checked by comparison of the experimental X-ray powder pattern with the simulated one generated from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S4). Furthermore, the FT-IR spectra of compounds 1 and 2 also verified the structures (Figure S5). The υ­(C–O) vibrations of the carboxylate linker are identified at 1568 (νasym), 1366 cm–1 (νsym) for 1, and 1602 (νasym), 1367 cm–1 (νsym) for 2. The signature of the TBA cations is found around 1465 and 1470 cm–1, respectively, in compounds 1 and 2. The υ­(P–O) and υ­(Mo–Od) vibrations of the Keggin skeleton are encountered around 1061 and 937 cm–1 in 1, and 1108 and 932 cm–1 in 2. The υ­(Mo–Ob–Mo) and υ­(Mo–Oc–Mo) vibrations are found around 818 and 782 cm–1 in 1, and 820 and 776 cm–1 in 2.

The υ(C-O) vibrations of the carboxylate linker are identified at 1568 (νasym), 1366 cm-1 (νsym) for 1, and 1602 (νasym), 1367 cm-1 (νsym) for 2. The signature of the TBA cations is found around 1465 and 1470 cm-1, respectively, in compounds 1 and 2. The υ(P-O) and υ(Mo-Od) vibrations of the Keggin skeleton are encountered around 1061 and 937 cm-1 in 1, and 1108 and 932 cm-1 in 2. The υ(Mo-Ob-Mo) and υ(Mo-Oc-Mo) vibrations are found around 818 and 782 cm-1 in 1, and 820 and 776 cm-1 in 2.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Fdd2 space group. The asymmetric unit (omitted the counter-cations) contains one {ε-Keggin 1} and one-half of {ε-Keggin 2} anions, six crystallographically independent Zn2+ centers, and two L1 ligands (Figure S6). Each Zn4-ε-Keggin fragment, acting as regular inorganic tetrahedra, is connected with eight adjacent clusters through the 3-connected L1 molecules (, Figure S7). Such connectivity leads to a 3D extended (3,4)-connected framework with (6 84 10)3(62 8)4 topology. The solvent-accessible voids calculated by PLATON for the structure without the contribution of TBA amount to the very large value of 67839.0 Å3 and represents 58.1% of the total volume of the structure.
elements.clean_text:
Descriptions of the Crystal Structures

YZU-103

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Fdd2 space group. The asymmetric unit (omitted the counter-cations) contains one {ε-Keggin 1} and one-half of {ε-Keggin 2} anions, six crystallographically independent Zn2+ centers, and two L1 ligands (Figure S6). Each Zn4-ε-Keggin fragment, acting as regular inorganic tetrahedra, is connected with eight adjacent clusters through the 3-connected L1 molecules (, Figure S7). Such connectivity leads to a 3D extended (3,4)-connected framework with (6 84 10)3(62 8)4 topology. The solvent-accessible voids calculated by PLATON for the structure without the contribution of TBA amount to the very large value of 67839.0 Å3 and represents 58.1% of the total volume of the structure.

elements.clean_text: 2  Polyhedral and schematic presentations of the 8-connected Zn4-ε-Keggin fragment constructed by {ε-Keggin 1} (a) and {ε-Keggin 2} (b); (c) Illustration of the 3D (3,4)-connected framework of 1.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group. The asymmetric unit contains one ε-Keggin anion, four crystallographically independent Zn2+ centers, two HL2 ligands, three TBA+ counterions, and one-half lattice water molecule (Figure S8). Each HL2 ligand employs two carboxylate groups joining to the coordination and leaves one uncoordinated, that is, the carboxylates attaching to rings A and O in HL2-l, and the carboxylates attaching to rings A and B in HL2-2 are involving in the coordination (Figure S9). The peripheral aromatic rings A and B are twisted from the central ring O by 12.3° and 18.9°, respectively, for HL2-1, and 36.5° and 37.1°, respectively, for HL2-2. The HL2-2 exhibits small dihedral angle difference of 0.6° due to the equal steric hindrance effect of the substituents on the central benzene ring. However, for HL2-1, a slightly bigger value of 6.6° is obtained thanks to the uncoordinated carboxylate in ring B which brings out much freedom of twist. In consideration of the extension, each HL2 ligand acts as a 2-connected node with bent angle of 126 ± 1°, which shows a similar connection style with that of 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate in {ε­(isop)2} and 5-methylisophthalic acid in YZU-101. Under the influence of the “angular linker” of HL2, each {Zn4-(HL2)2-ε-Keggin} fragment exhibits a distorted tetrahedral geometry (a). As a result, a 2D (44) network is formed. The P···P distance between adjacent polyoxoanions is ca. 23.6 Å along a axis, and ca. 20.0 Å along b axis. The adjacent 2D sheets are staggered in a ABCDABCD style, as shown in b (Figure S10).

The asymmetric unit contains one ε-Keggin anion, four crystallographically independent Zn2+ centers, two HL2 ligands, three TBA+ counterions, and one-half lattice water molecule (Figure S8). Each HL2 ligand employs two carboxylate groups joining to the coordination and leaves one uncoordinated, that is, the carboxylates attaching to rings A and O in HL2-l, and the carboxylates attaching to rings A and B in HL2-2 are involving in the coordination (Figure S9). The peripheral aromatic rings A and B are twisted from the central ring O by 12.3° and 18.9°, respectively, for HL2-1, and 36.5° and 37.1°, respectively, for HL2-2. The HL2-2 exhibits small dihedral angle difference of 0.6° due to the equal steric hindrance effect of the substituents on the central benzene ring. However, for HL2-1, a slightly bigger value of 6.6° is obtained thanks to the uncoordinated carboxylate in ring B which brings out much freedom of twist. In consideration of the extension, each HL2 ligand acts as a 2-connected node with bent angle of 126 ± 1°, which shows a similar connection style with that of 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate in {ε(isop)2} and 5-methylisophthalic acid in YZU-101. Under the influence of the "angular linker" of HL2, each {Zn4-(HL2)2-ε-Keggin} fragment exhibits a distorted tetrahedral geometry (a). As a result, a 2D (44) network is formed. elements.content: A 3D (3,4)-connected compound ε­(trim)4/3 with ofp-like topology was constructed through the combination of triangular linker of 1,3,5-H3BTC and tetrahedral Zn4-ε-Keggin fragment in previous work. It crystallizes in orthorhombic I222 space group with the unit cell parameters of a = 21.6212(10) Å, b = 22.5502(10) Å, c = 42.1069(17) Å, V = 20529.7(16) Å3, and Z = 6. For the triangular linker, it exhibits smaller angles of 14.7°, 13.9°, and 15.7° for the dihedral angles between the carboxylate groups and the central benzene ring (a). A schematic representation about the extension was introduced to better understand the symmetry and extending direction of the tripodal ligand, as shown in , while the atom O′ represents the dummy atom in the central benzene ring, and atoms A′, B′, C′ represent the central P atoms in each ε-Keggin block. The 1,3,5-H3BTC exhibits approximate regular triangle with each upholding length of ca. 9 Å and each intersection angles of 120 ± 4°.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Discussion

A 3D (3,4)-connected compound ε(trim)4/3 with ofp-like topology was constructed through the combination of triangular linker of 1,3,5-H3BTC and tetrahedral Zn4-ε-Keggin fragment in previous work. It crystallizes in orthorhombic I222 space group with the unit cell parameters of a = 21.6212(10) Å, b = 22.5502(10) Å, c = 42.1069(17) Å, V = 20529.7(16) Å3, and Z = 6. For the triangular linker, it exhibits smaller angles of 14.7°, 13.9°, and 15.7° for the dihedral angles between the carboxylate groups and the central benzene ring (a). A schematic representation about the extension was introduced to better understand the symmetry and extending direction of the tripodal ligand, as shown in , while the atom O' represents the dummy atom in the central benzene ring, and atoms A', B', C' represent the central P atoms in each ε-Keggin block. The 1,3,5-H3BTC exhibits approximate regular triangle with each upholding length of ca. 9 Å and each intersection angles of 120 ± 4°.

elements.content: Structural comparisons of three (3,4)-connected frameworks: (a) ofp-like structure of ε­(trim)4/3, (b) ctn-like structure of NENU-500, and (c) yzu-like structure of 1.
elements.clean_text: 4  Structural comparisons of three (3,4)-connected frameworks: (a) ofp-like structure of ε(trim)4/3, (b) ctn-like structure of NENU-500, and (c) yzu-like structure of 1.

elements.content: When an elongated linker of H3BTB was introduced, much bigger dihedral angles, between the central aromatic ring (O) and the adjacent rings (A, B, and C), of 41.8° (AO), 42.6° (BO), and 41.9° (CO) are exhibited in compound NENU-500 with ctn-like (3,4)-connected topology (b). It crystallizes in cubic Ia3̅d space group with the unit cell parameters of a = b = c = 48.9280(13) Å, V = 117131.7(5) Å3, and Z = 24. It creates more structural diversity via the rotation of the aromatic ring than that of 1,3,5-H3BTC. Thanks to the equal steric hindrance effect of the substituents on the central benzene ring, it causes similar variations of adjacent aromatic rings from planarity with respect to the central ring. A regular triangle was obtained in NENU-500 with an enlargement of each upholding length from ca. 9 Å to ca. 13 Å through the replacement of 1,3,5-H3BTC. The intersection angles are all ca. 118°, indicating a little deviation from the plane.

It creates more structural diversity via the rotation of the aromatic ring than that of 1,3,5-H3BTC. Thanks to the equal steric hindrance effect of the substituents on the central benzene ring, it causes similar variations of adjacent aromatic rings from planarity with respect to the central ring. elements.content: With the help of 3,5′,3″-substituted H3L1, a (3,4)-connected framework of YZU-103 with the unprecedented topology (yzu) of (6·84·10)3(62·8)4 has been obtained (c). It crystallizes in orthorhombic Fdd2 space group with the unit cell parameters of a = 52.935(4) Å, b = 55.018(4) Å, c = 23.2930(15) Å, V = 67839(8) Å3, and Z = 8. After careful examination of the structure, we found four particular characteristics standing out: (i) The peripheral aromatic rings A and B are fairly twisted with respect to the central ring by 65.9° and 26.3°, respectively, for L1-1, and 61.2°, 23.0°, respectively, for L1-2, because of the bigger steric hindrance effect. It shows great differences of ca. 38.2–39.6° between the dihedral angles of AO and BO. (ii) It leads to great compression of ∠A′O′C′ (ca. 101.1° in L1-1 and ca. 91.7° in L1-2) and ∠A′O′B′ (ca. 80.7° in L1-1 and ca. 82.0° in L1-2), and expansion of ∠B′O′C′ (ca. 160.0° in L1-1 and ca. 148.2° in L1-2) relative to the ideal 120°. (iii) The sum for the intersection angles (ca. 341.9° in L1-1 and ca. 322.0° in L1-2) is greatly decreased in both 3-connected ligands, indicating a severe destruction of the coplanarity of the extension. (iv) Shrinkage from H3BTB to H3L1 led to a shortening of axis c, which corresponds to a shortening of the O′C′ from ca. 13 Å to ca. 9 Å; The lengths of O′A′ and O′B′ also shrink from ca. 13 Å to ca. 11 Å, due to the great compression of ∠A′O′C′ and ∠B′O′C′. All these structural features lead to a unique tripodal linker with different length, extending direction, and symmetry, as compared to those of H3BTC and H3BTB, which perhaps can account for the distinct topology it has.
elements.clean_text: With the help of 3,5',3"-substituted H3L1, a (3,4)-connected framework of YZU-103 with the unprecedented topology (yzu) of (6⋅84⋅10)3(62⋅8)4 has been obtained (c). It crystallizes in orthorhombic Fdd2 space group with the unit cell parameters of a = 52.935(4) Å, b = 55.018(4) Å, c = 23.2930(15) Å, V = 67839(8) Å3, and Z = 8. After careful examination of the structure, we found four particular characteristics standing out: (i) The peripheral aromatic rings A and B are fairly twisted with respect to the central ring by 65.9° and 26.3°, respectively, for L1-1, and 61.2°, 23.0°, respectively, for L1-2, because of the bigger steric hindrance effect. It shows great differences of ca. 38.2-39.6° between the dihedral angles of AO and BO. (ii) It leads to great compression of ∠A'O'C' (ca. 101.1° in L1-1 and ca. 91.7° in L1-2) and ∠A'O'B' (ca. 80.7° in L1-1 and ca. 82.0° in L1-2), and expansion of ∠B'O'C' (ca. 160.0° in L1-1 and ca. 148.2° in L1-2) relative to the ideal 120°. (iii) The sum for the intersection angles (ca. 341.9° in L1-1 and ca. 322.0° in L1-2) is greatly decreased in both 3-connected ligands, indicating a severe destruction of the coplanarity of the extension. (iv) Shrinkage from H3BTB to H3L1 led to a shortening of axis c, which corresponds to a shortening of the O'C' from ca. 13 Å to ca. 9 Å; The lengths of O'A' and O'B' also shrink from ca. 13 Å to ca. 11 Å, due to the great compression of ∠A'O'C' and ∠B'O'C'. All these structural features lead to a unique tripodal linker with different length, extending direction, and symmetry, as compared to those of H3BTC and H3BTB, which perhaps can account for the distinct topology it has.

elements.content: In conclusion, for linking tetrahedra and triangles into 3-periodic arrays, the extending direction, symmetry, and length have important effect on the topology of frameworks. The elongated tripodal ligand would create more structural diversity via the rotation of the aromatic ring. The substituents in the different positions would cause different extents of the twist of the peripheral aromatic ring with respect to the central ring, as a result, giving rise to different extending direction and symmetry.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates are known to exhibit well-defined redox waves and are usually considered to be electron reservoirs. Electrochemistry of POMs has been attracting extensive interest in electrocatalytic oxidation of ascorbic acid, and reduction of bromate, Cr­(VI), and nitrite. Bromate (BrO3 –) is considered a potent cancer-inducing agent and is generally found in drinking water samples. Due to its health and environmental implications, efficient technologies are required for bromate removal and determination from drinking water. Among numerous techniques including adsorption, membrane treatment, UV radiation, and coprecipitation, an electrochemical approach provides a suitable method since it is relatively clean, environmentally friendly, highly selective, and cost efficient. It is expected that the entrapment of POMs in a 3D configuration could induce huge enhancement of their electrocatalytic activity. In this context, compounds of 1 and 2 were employed to the POMOFs modified glassy carbon electrodes (GCEs) for the electrocatalytic reduction of bromate.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry and Bromate Reduction Electrocatalysis

Polyoxometalates are known to exhibit well-defined redox waves and are usually considered to be electron reservoirs. Electrochemistry of POMs has been attracting extensive interest in electrocatalytic oxidation of ascorbic acid, and reduction of bromate, Cr(VI), and nitrite. Bromate (BrO3 -) is considered a potent cancer-inducing agent and is generally found in drinking water samples. Due to its health and environmental implications, efficient technologies are required for bromate removal and determination from drinking water. Among numerous techniques including adsorption, membrane treatment, UV radiation, and coprecipitation, an electrochemical approach provides a suitable method since it is relatively clean, environmentally friendly, highly selective, and cost efficient. It is expected that the entrapment of POMs in a 3D configuration could induce huge enhancement of their electrocatalytic activity. In this context, compounds of 1 and 2 were employed to the POMOFs modified glassy carbon electrodes (GCEs) for the electrocatalytic reduction of bromate.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammograms for 1–2 modified GCEs in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution recorded at different scan rates (varying from 20 to 160 mV s–1) are shown in . In the potential range of −150 to 600 mV, three quasi-reversible redox peaks were observed. The halfwave potentials of E 1/2 are 315 (I–I′), 184 (II–II′), and −79 mV (III–III′) for 1, and 316 (I–I′), 185 (II–II′), and −72 mV (III–III′) for 2, respectively (E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2; E pa and E pc are the anodic and cathodic peak potential, respectively, scan rate: 50 mV s–1). The peak potentials changed gradually whereas the cathodic peak potentials shift to negative direction and the corresponding anodic peak potentials shift to positive direction with increasing scan rates. The anodic and cathodic peak currents are linearly proportional to scan rate up to 160 mV s–1, suggesting that the electrochemical behavior of the POMOFs is not a diffusion-controlled process but a surface-controlled one, as illustrated by the linear plots (II–II′ peak) in Figure S11.

The halfwave potentials of E 1/2 are 315 (I-I'), 184 (II-II'), and -79 mV (III-III') for 1, and 316 (I-I'), 185 (II-II'), and -72 mV (III-III') for 2, respectively (E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2; E pa and E pc are the anodic and cathodic peak potential, respectively, scan rate: 50 mV s-1). The peak potentials changed gradually whereas the cathodic peak potentials shift to negative direction and the corresponding anodic peak potentials shift to positive direction with increasing scan rates. The anodic and cathodic peak currents are linearly proportional to scan rate up to 160 mV s-1, suggesting that the electrochemical behavior of the POMOFs is not a diffusion-controlled process but a surface-controlled one, as illustrated by the linear plots (II-II' peak) in Figure S11.

elements.content: shows the cyclic voltamograms of 1–2 modified GCEs in 0.1 M H2SO4 in the absence and presence of 1.0–5.0 mM bromate. With the addition 1.0 mM of bromate, the reduction peak currents around the second (II–II′) and third (III–III′) redox pairs increase and the corresponding oxidation peak currents decrease at all the electrodes, suggesting that the reduced forms of 1–2 formed in these processes both exhibit effective catalytic activity toward bromate reduction. In order to obtain the sensitivity and detection limits at lower concentration for bromate, chronoamperometric detection of bromate were studied in a stirred solution of 0.1 M H2SO4 with successive injections of 10, 50, or 100 μM of bromate, as shown in and Figure S12. The applied potentials were set at +156 mV, and +146 mV, respectively, for 1–2 GCEs. The analytical data including the electrolyte media, linear range, and sensitivity were summarized in . For 1-GCE sensor, as the concentration of BrO3 – increased, the reduction current was increased linearly (). Within a response time of less than 2s, a sharp rise in current was observed. The linear dependence (correlation coefficients >0.99) yielded the regression equations of I 1(μA) = 2.28–29.86 × [BrO3 –] (mM). However, a stable plateau was solely observed with each addition of bromate in 1-GCE sensor. On the contrary, rapid decline in current was observed with each addition of bromate in 2-GCE sensor (Figure S12). This fact indicates that the entrapment of POMs in a 3D configuration is more in favor of obtaining stable current response. The sensitivity of the 1-GCE sensor obtained from the slope of the linear part of the calibration curve is 422.42 μA cm–2 mM–1, which is higher than those of phosphomolybdate-doped conducting polymer composite material modified glassy carbon electrodes, e.g., PMo12/PEDOT/AuNP/GC, PMo12/CNTs/PPy, and PMo12/CNTs/PEDOT.

In summary, by the virtue of a 3,5′,3″-substituted terphenyl-based tricarboxylate H3L1, we constructed a polyoxometalate-based metal–organic framework of YZU-103, which exhibits an unprecedented (3,4)-connected yzu topology on the basis of tetrahedral {Zn4-ε-Keggin} building block. The successful isolation of YZU-103 confirms the feasibility of the methodology that combination of tetrahedral inorganic building blocks and rigid triangular organic linkers to construct (3,4)-connected nets. However, for linking tetrahedra and triangles into 3-periodic arrays, the length, symmetry, and extending direction of the tripodal ligand have an important effect on the topology of the framework. The elongated tripodal ligand would create more structural diversity via the rotation of the aromatic ring. The substituents in the different positions would cause different extent of the twist of the peripheral aromatic ring with respect to the central ring, as a result, giving rise to different extending direction and symmetry. This finding is best exemplified by the isolation of YZU-104 with 44 network. Moreover, the electrocatalytic activities of 1–2 modified GCEs toward the reduction of bromate were examined. The sensitivities of the 1-GCE is 422.42 μAcm–2 mM–1, which is higher than some phosphomolybdate-doped conducting polymers composite material modified glassy carbon electrodes. Furthermore, 1-GCE exhibits more stable current response than that of 2-GCE sensor, indicating the enhancement of electrocatalytic activity when entrapping POMs in the 3D configuration.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, by the virtue of a 3,5',3"-substituted terphenyl-based tricarboxylate H3L1, we constructed a polyoxometalate-based metal-organic framework of YZU-103, which exhibits an unprecedented (3,4)-connected yzu topology on the basis of tetrahedral {Zn4-ε-Keggin} building block. The successful isolation of YZU-103 confirms the feasibility of the methodology that combination of tetrahedral inorganic building blocks and rigid triangular organic linkers to construct (3,4)-connected nets. However, for linking tetrahedra and triangles into 3-periodic arrays, the length, symmetry, and extending direction of the tripodal ligand have an important effect on the topology of the framework. The elongated tripodal ligand would create more structural diversity via the rotation of the aromatic ring. The substituents in the different positions would cause different extent of the twist of the peripheral aromatic ring with respect to the central ring, as a result, giving rise to different extending direction and symmetry. This finding is best exemplified by the isolation of YZU-104 with 44 network. Moreover, the electrocatalytic activities of 1-2 modified GCEs toward the reduction of bromate were examined. The sensitivities of the 1-GCE is 422.42 μAcm-2 mM-1, which is higher than some phosphomolybdate-doped conducting polymers composite material modified glassy carbon electrodes. Furthermore, 1-GCE exhibits more stable current response than that of 2-GCE sensor, indicating the enhancement of electrocatalytic activity when entrapping POMs in the 3D configuration.

10.0 mL of distilled water was added to a beaker, which contains Na2MoO4·2H2O (1.26 g, 5.20 mmol), Mo powder (0.10 g, 1.04 mmol), ZnCl2 (0.28 g, 2.00 mmol), H3PO3 (0.05 g, 0.56 mmol), and tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH, 0.25 g, 0.77 mmol) with stirring for 20 min. Next, the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 3.6 with 2 mol/L HCl and then the mixture was stirred for another 30 min followed by the addition of H3L1 (0.11 g, 0.30 mmol). Then the mixture was transferred and sealed in a 23.0 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, and heated at 180 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals 1 were collected and dried in air (yield: ca. 0.70 g). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C76H128N3PMo12O48Zn4: C, 27.67; H, 3.88; N, 1.27; Zn, 7.93; Mo, 34.93%; Found: C, 27.62; H, 3.82; N, 1.21; Zn, 7.85; Mo, 34.88%. Prominent FT-IR peaks for 1 (KBr Pellet, cm–1): 2960(s), 2877(s), 1719­(w), 1568(s), 1465­(m), 1366(s), 1164 (m), 1061 (w), 937(s), 818(s), 782(s), 699(s), 585(s), 549­(m), 491­(m).

cln_elements.content: A 3D (3,4)-connected compound ε­(trim)4/3 with ofp-like topology was constructed through the combination of triangular linker of 1,3,5-H3BTC and tetrahedral Zn4-ε-Keggin fragment in previous work. It crystallizes in orthorhombic I222 space group with the unit cell parameters of a = 21.6212(10) Å, b = 22.5502(10) Å, c = 42.1069(17) Å, V = 20529.7(16) Å3, and Z = 6. For the triangular linker, it exhibits smaller angles of 14.7°, 13.9°, and 15.7° for the dihedral angles between the carboxylate groups and the central benzene ring (a). A schematic representation about the extension was introduced to better understand the symmetry and extending direction of the tripodal ligand, as shown in , while the atom O′ represents the dummy atom in the central benzene ring, and atoms A′, B′, C′ represent the central P atoms in each ε-Keggin block. The 1,3,5-H3BTC exhibits approximate regular triangle with each upholding length of ca. 9 Å and each intersection angles of 120 ± 4°.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Structural Discussion

A 3D (3,4)-connected compound ε(trim)4/3 with ofp-like topology was constructed through the combination of triangular linker of 1,3,5-H3BTC and tetrahedral Zn4-ε-Keggin fragment in previous work. It crystallizes in orthorhombic I222 space group with the unit cell parameters of a = 21.6212(10) Å, b = 22.5502(10) Å, c = 42.1069(17) Å, V = 20529.7(16) Å3, and Z = 6. For the triangular linker, it exhibits smaller angles of 14.7°, 13.9°, and 15.7° for the dihedral angles between the carboxylate groups and the central benzene ring (a). A schematic representation about the extension was introduced to better understand the symmetry and extending direction of the tripodal ligand, as shown in , while the atom O' represents the dummy atom in the central benzene ring, and atoms A', B', C' represent the central P atoms in each ε-Keggin block. The 1,3,5-H3BTC exhibits approximate regular triangle with each upholding length of ca. 9 Å and each intersection angles of 120 ± 4°.
